reasoning: The critique targets the paper’s move from acknowledged intertheoretic-comparison fragility to a relatively confident, action-relevant takeaway (“easygoingness unlikely”, “fussy views loom larger”). If that move failed, the headline would need more qualification, but much of the paper’s case for “no easy eutopia” also rests on object-level fragility/multiplicative-factor arguments and the bounded/unbounded ‘fussiness’ taxonomy that do not hinge on a single normalization choice—so centrality is moderate, not total. The critique’s force is also moderate: it correctly notes that different plausible moral-uncertainty aggregation schemes can reverse strategy rankings and that this undercuts practical confidence, but it doesn’t closely engage with the paper’s specific defenses of variance normalization/pairwise scaling or show that those are unreasonable; it mostly gestures at alternative meta-ethical frameworks without arguing they are (i) plausible enough and (ii) would materially rehabilitate ‘easy eutopia’ rather than merely shifting decision guidance. Relevance is high because moral uncertainty / intertheoretic comparisons and how they affect prioritisation are live (Tier 3-adjacent) issues in Forethought’s agenda. Overall, it’s a useful cautionary pressure on robustness but not a decisive refutation.
title: "Moral uncertainty vitiates the paper's practical confidence"
